title: 111_hr5334
content: The Act is titled the "Rio Grande del Norte National Conservation Area Establishment Act" and includes definitions for key terms. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms related to the Rio Grande del Norte National Conservation Area, including Conservation Area, land grant community, management plan, map, Secretary, and State. The Rio Grande del Norte National Conservation Area is established in Taos and Rio Arriba counties, covering approximately 235,980 acres of public land. The purposes are to conserve and protect cultural, traditional, archaeological, natural, ecological, geological, historical, wildlife, educational, recreational, and scenic resources. The Secretary will manage the area to enhance its resources in accordance with specified guidelines. The Conservation Area, established in Taos and Rio Arriba counties, covers 235,980 acres. The Secretary will manage it to enhance resources in accordance with laws and guidelines. Motorized vehicle use is restricted to designated roads for non-emergency purposes. The Conservation Area in Taos and Rio Arriba counties covers 235,980 acres and is managed to enhance resources. Motorized vehicle use is limited to designated roads. No new roads can be built unless for public safety or natural resource protection. Grazing is allowed within the area, subject to laws and regulations. The Conservation Area allows for traditional collection of firewood, medicinal plants, herbs, and pinon nuts for personal use, in accordance with laws and Secretary's terms. Upgrading of utility right-of-ways is permitted with minimal harm to Conservation Area purposes. The Conservation Area, as outlined in subsection (b), must comply with the National Environmental Policy Act and other relevant laws, and adhere to terms set by the Secretary. The Secretary, in consultation with Indian tribes or pueblos, must protect religious and cultural sites within the Conservation Area and provide access to these sites. The Conservation Area must comply with relevant laws and terms set by the Secretary. The Secretary, in consultation with Indian tribes or pueblos, must protect religious and cultural sites within the area and provide access for traditional uses, including temporary closures when requested. The Secretary must develop a management plan for the Conservation Area within 3 years, consulting with state and local governments, tribal entities, land grant communities, and the public. The plan may include the Rio Grande Corridor Management Plan. The Secretary must consider recommendations from Indian tribes and pueblos on ensuring access to religious and cultural sites, enhancing privacy and continuity of traditional activities, and protecting cultural sites in the Conservation Area. Acquired land within the boundary of the Conservation Area becomes part of it and must be managed according to the Act. The Conservation Area must be managed in accordance with the Act and other applicable laws. The establishment of the Conservation Area does not change the management status of areas designated as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System or managed as areas of critical environmental concern. In case of a conflict, the more restrictive provision between laws shall control. SEC. 4. DESIGNATION OF WILDERNESS AREAS. Designated wilderness areas in the Conservation Area include Cerro del Yuta Wilderness in Taos County, New Mexico (13,420 acres) and Rio San Antonio Wilderness in Rio Arriba County, New Mexico (8,000 acres). These areas are managed in accordance with the Wilderness Act. The wilderness areas designated in the Conservation Area shall be administered according to the Wilderness Act and this Act. Any land acquired within these areas becomes part of the wilderness area and is managed in accordance with the Wilderness Act. Grazing of livestock in designated wilderness areas shall be administered according to the Wilderness Act and other applicable laws. Buffer zones are not created around wilderness areas, and activities outside these areas are not restricted. The text chunk discusses that activities or land use outside designated wilderness areas should not be restricted if they can be seen or heard within the wilderness area. It also mentions that the San Antonio Wilderness Study Area has been adequately studied for wilderness designation and should be managed accordingly. SEC. 5. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The Secretary must file maps and legal descriptions of the Conservation Area and designated wilderness areas with relevant committees, with the same legal force as if included in the Act, allowing for corrections. The information will be available for public inspection. The Conservation Area and designated wilderness areas will be administered as part of the National Landscape Conservation System. The Act does not affect the State's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife on public land, but the Secretary can designate hunting zones for safety or public use reasons. Federal land within these areas is subject to withdrawals, with exceptions for valid existing rights. Section 4(a) of the Act withdraws land or interest in land acquired by the United States from entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land laws, location, entry, and patent under mining laws, and operation of mineral leasing laws. The Act does not affect treaty rights. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the Act.
